items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecasted unsettled weather conditions during coming tides. Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston between 01:00 PM and 06:00 PM today, Monday 19/12/2022. Weather conditions are expected to produce large onshore waves, with particular areas at risk being frontages around South Pier and the Lifeboat Station in Bridlington. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 19/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

"This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we will continue to monitor the situation.  
"

A flood alert has been issued for this afternoons tide at 2:37pm on the 19th December 2022. There will be southerly force 7 winds and large waves. Area most at risk is Chiswell, Chesil Beach. We continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Wey in the Bordon area as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. 
Further rainfall is forecast today. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 19/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels are currently below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.  Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels are currently below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.  Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Chetnole and other river gauges as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and farmland is possible overnight, between 18/12/22 and 19/12/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and please avoid the ford at Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.   
  We expect river levels to rise until the early hours of 19/12/22.
Our incident response staff have cleared weed screens. And we are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated on 19/12/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Esk due to rainfall and melting snow.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Esk, with low-lying land expected to be most affected, particularly in the Esk Valley and some minor roads. 

Flooding is possible from 10:00 AM on 19/12/2022.

Snowmelt is expected to continue as temperatures rise through the day, this will keep levels on the river high. 
We will continue to monitor local river levels and weather conditions closely.

Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water.

Consider putting your flood plan into action. 

Plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 19/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message: Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride, with low lying land expected to be most affected. River levels are rising at Beaminster, Burton Bradstock, Charmouth, Chideock, Jessops Avenue, Netherbury, Powerstock and Uplyme The Glebelands gauge. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours. River levels can rise very quickly in response to rainfall. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 am on 19/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

The River Uck is high following 30mm of rain on Sunday. In Isfield, the River Uck will continue to rise until 09:00 on 19/12/2022, and flood water could approach properties at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge. In Buxted and Uckfield, the River Uck is falling. However, another 5mm of rain is forecast between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022. A further 15mm of rain is also possible on Monday evening. Minor flood impacts could return to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub and areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. Areas in Uckfield most at risk include The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage and Bell Walk. The river might not begin to finally fall until Tuesday (20/12/2022) and with unsettled weather forecast, it could remain higher than normal all week. As a precaution, we recommend keeping flood protection products installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:30 on 19/12/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected between 6am this morning until Tuesday evening, 20 December 2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around the Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst and also low-lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Balls Green and Ashurst. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday, 21 December 2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and our partners and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 

This message will be updated this evening, Monday 19 December 2022, or as the situation changes.

Water levels at Alverstone and Sandown on the Eastern Yar are rising following rain over the last 24 hours. Over half a month's rain (46mm) was recorded at Wroxall. Levels will peak at Alverstone later today (19/12/2022) and continue to rise at Sandown. This morning the river will come out of bank at Whitwell High Street and Langbridge. It will restrict access to Horringford and be close to the bank top at Alverstone. By 12:30, it will flood Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road. This afternoon, levels will be high at Sandown Bridge, the sewage treatment plant and Fort Holiday Park. Further rain is forecast. While levels at Alverstone will fall, they likely will rise higher this evening and overnight. Be prepared for the river to be higher than normal for the next few days. Today properties are likely to flood but exact timings depend on the rainfall. We are likely to issue a Flood Warning for Alverstone later. If you live near the river, take action now to protect your property. This message will be updated by 16:00 on 19/12/2022 or sooner if we think property flooding will occur.

The River Ouse is high and rising between Scayne's Hill and Barcombe, following 30mm of rain Sunday. Minor flood impacts are expected to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties all along the Upper Ouse, including near Dean's Water Mill, Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. The Anchor Inn at Barcombe Mills will likely flood and Barcombe Mills Road is likely to be impassable. A further 5mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 Monday 19/12/2022, and another 15mm of rain possible Monday evening too. It is possible the River Ouse could rise a little higher Monday afternoon and Tuesday. With unsettled weather, the River Ouse through Barcombe could remain higher than normal all week. As a precaution, we recommend keeping flood protection products installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 16:30 19/12/2022.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Monday 19th December 2022. River levels are stable, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Haverhill, Clare and Sudbury, including Kedington, Sturmer, Steeple Bumpstead, Cavendish, Bridge Street and Long Melford. There may be some further light rainfall overnight. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 20th November.

The Bull River through Hellingly is high and rising, following 30mm of rain on Sunday. Property flooding is expected to affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Flooding is also expected to affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. A further 5mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022, and another 15mm of rain is possible on Monday evening too. This could cause river levels to rise higher and fall later. While the Cuckmere River through Hellingly is currently falling, this additional rain could potentially cause flood impacts to again affect Mill Lane, Hellingly and Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. River levels could remain higher than normal all week. Plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:30 on 19/12/2022.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected between 6am this morning until Tuesday evening, 20 December 2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around the Crowhurst Bridge area and Shrub Lane and also around Robertsbridge. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday, 21 December 2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and our partners, and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 

This message will be updated this evening, Monday 19 December 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen on the river Mole from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham and Sidlow as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land close to watercourses in the area is expected between 12:30 pm today 19/12/2022 and tomorrow evening, 20/12/22. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours until tomorrow morning.  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow evening. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.

This message will be updated by 17:00 today, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 25mm of rain has been recorded at Cowfold, which is a lot in a short period. From 10:00 on 19/12/2022, flooding will affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. Flooding will also affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury and there will be extensive water in fields. A further 10mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022, and another 15mm of rain is possible on Monday evening too. The river might not finally begin to fall until Tuesday afternoon (20/12/2022) and could remain higher than normal for much of the week. If the River Adur receives the maximum rainfall amounts, river levels could rise as high as the peak during November 2022. Some roads may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including the A281 at Mock Bridge. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:30 on 19/12/2022.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Monday 19th December 2022. River levels are stabilising, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. There may be some further light rainfall overnight. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 20th December.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The Medway is forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall on Sunday and Monday. Flooding of low lying land and riverside paths is expected between 1pm this afternoon, 19 December, and Tuesday evening, 20 December. We expect flooding to affect the riverside paths in Maidstone first, followed by the Wateringbury, East Farleigh and Teston areas. Internal flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours and we expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday, 21 December. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking our structures to ensure the river can flow freely.  We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated this evening, 19 December, or as the situation changes.

The Bull River is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 30mm of rain has been recorded at Cowbeech, which is a lot in a short period. From 09:30 on 19/12/2022, flooding will affect properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. The Cuckmere River is currently falling, but as more rain is forecast Monday morning and evening, flood impacts are possible on Mill Lane, Hellingly and at Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. Another 5mm of rain is forecast between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022. A further 10mm of rain is possible on Monday evening. The river might not begin to finally fall until 12:00 on Tuesday 20/12/2022, and with a week of unsettled weather ahead, might not return nearer to normal until the end of the week. River levels should end up a little lower than their peak in November 2022. Some roads including Mill Road and Church Road may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 on 19/12/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
While the risk of flooding from rivers in the Upper Tamar has now reduced, a Flood Alert remains in force. Further rain is forecast this afternoon and evening on Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise late afternoon and into the evening.

Take care near the areas of concern and be aware of your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels throughout the day and this message will be updated by 5pm Monday 19th December.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 35mm of rain has been recorded at Cowbeech. From 11:00 on 19/12/2022, flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens, and properties including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and properties near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Another 10mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022, with showers possible Monday evening and through Tuesday morning too. The river might not begin to fall until 12:00 on Tuesday 20/12/2022. With unsettled weather predicted for the next five days, the Cuckmere River might not return nearer to normal until the end of the week. River levels could peak at a height similar to November 2022. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:30 on 19/12/2022.

The Western Rother is high and rising between Midhurst and Fittleworth, following 30mm of rain Sunday. Another 20mm of rain is possible before 09:00 Tuesday 20/12/2022. The Western Rother could rise again in all communities. From 21:00 19/12/2022, minor flooding could affect Station Road Liss, and Mill Lane and Old Mill Lane, Sheet. From 01:00 20/12/2022, minor flood impacts could affect Iping, Stedham and The Wharf, and nearby fields in Midhurst. From 16:00 19/12/2022, flood water could be very close to properties at Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth, and potentially rise higher, affecting properties Tuesday. Properties on the Lod near Lickfold Bridge could also be affected. The river may not begin to finally fall until midday Tuesday 20/12/2022 in Liss, and Wednesday nearer Fittleworth. Between Midhurst and Fittleworth, river levels could remain higher than normal all week. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:30 19/12/2022.

The Langney Haven is high and rising, following 40mm of rainfall on Sunday. Flooding will continue to affect gardens of Langney Green. Fields and parkland, including Shinewater Park, will also be affected. Another 5mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022, and a further 15mm of rain is possible on Monday evening too. Flood water could get closer to properties on Langney Green from 18:00 on 19/12/2022. The river might not begin to fall until Tuesday 20/12/2022. With unsettled weather forecast for the next five days, river levels will remain higher than normal all week, and probably into January 2023. As a precaution, we recommend keeping flood protection products installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles Gate to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. From 17:00 on 19/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

The Powdermill Stream through Crowhurst is very high, following 40mm of rain Sunday. Flooding will continue to affect fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, rural roads, gardens and will be very close to properties in Crowhurst, including riverside properties on Forewood Lane and properties between The Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. Flood water will also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Another 5mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 Monday 19/12/2022, and a further 15mm of rain is possible Monday evening too. River levels could rise again, and potentially higher. If the predicted rain occurs, then flooding of properties is still possible in Crowhurst. The river should begin to fall by mid-morning Tuesday 20/12/2022, but could remain higher than normal much of the week. As a precaution, please keep flood protection products installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:30 19/12/2022.

The River Arun is high and rising, following 25mm of rain on Sunday. Only minor flooding is expected to affect fields, rural roads and gardens along the length of the River Arun, including at Tanbridge Park, Blackbridge Court and Arunside in Horsham, and isolated riverside properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay. Another 5mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022, and a further 15mm of rain is possible on Monday evening too. Flood impacts should remain minor. River levels should begin to fall by Tuesday afternoon (20/12/2022). However, the river could remain higher than normal all week. As a precaution, we recommend keeping flood protection products installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. From 17:00 on 19/12/2022, the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

The River Lox is higher than normal and rising, following 25mm of rain on Sunday. Minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and gardens along the length of the River Lox. Another 5mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022, and a further 15mm of rain is possible on Monday evening too. If the River Lox receives all this rain, it could rise higher and flood water could approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Minor flooding could also affect isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge, Dunsfold and on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. The river should begin to fall by Tuesday afternoon (20/12/2022), but with unsettled weather forecast for the next five days, the river could remain higher than normal all week. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. From 17:00 on 19/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Monday 19th December 2022. River levels are gently rising, and may remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street. There may be some further light rainfall overnight. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 20th December.

The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are higher than normal, following 35mm of rain Sunday. Only minor flood impacts are currently expected. A further 20mm of rain is possible Monday and through the early hours of Tuesday. If as much rain falls as predicted, from 21:00 19/12/2022 minor flooding could affect Marshall Close, Lake Lane and Barnham Road, Barnham, fields near Shripney Lane, parts of the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road, Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Aldingbourne Rife will probably not peak as high as it did in November. The river should begin to fall by 15:00 Tuesday 20/12/2022. However, river levels could remain higher than normal into January. As a precaution, we recommend keeping flood protection products installed in Barnham, if you have them. We routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. From 17:00 19/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday evening and overnight into Monday morning.
Throughout Sunday 18 December 2022 heavy rainfall has been falling in the Rivers Clyst and Culm area and is forecast to continue for the next couple of days causing rivers to rise.
Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected. 
We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the early part of this week and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Monday 19 December 2022 or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday evening and overnight into Monday morning.

Throughout Sunday 18 December 2022 heavy rainfall has been falling in the River Dart area and is forecast to continue for the next couple of days. This will cause water levels in the area to rise.

Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected. We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the early part of this week and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Monday 19 December 2022 or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Coly, River Yarty, Umborne Brook

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday evening and overnight into Monday morning.
Throughout Sunday 18 December 2022 heavy rainfall has been falling in the River Axe area and is forecast to continue for the next couple of days causing rivers to rise.
Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected. 
We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the early part of this week and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Monday 19 December 2022 or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teign, River Bovey, River Lemon, River Kenn

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday evening and overnight into Monday morning.

Throughout Sunday 18 December 2022 heavy rainfall has been falling in the River Teign area and is forecast to continue for the next couple of days.

Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected.

We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the early part of this week and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Monday 19 December 2022 or earlier if the situation changes.

The forecast is for strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. We are expecting total water levels to be high for this afternoon's high tide at 2.24pm on the 19th December with force 7 south westerly winds. Water levels could remain high for several hours. Areas most at risk include the inner harbour, East Beach and the esplanade on East Beach. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

River levels are rising on the River Ure and its tributaries due to rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ure, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The River Ure and tributaries from its source downstream to Kilgram. The main area of concern is around Snaizeholme Beck and Widdale Beck in Appersett. 
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning and afternoon.before clearing later in the day. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 19/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Chiselborough and other river gauges as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and farmland is possible overnight, between 18/12/22 and 19/12/22.  We expect flooding to affect the roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur.   
  We expect river levels to rise until the early hours of 19/12/22.
Our incident response staff have cleared weed screens. And we are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated on 19/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Plym, Tory Brook, Long Brook

items.message:
River levels remain high in the River Plym and Tory Brook and a Flood Alert remains in force.  

Further rain is forecast this afternoon and evening on Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise late afternoon and into the evening.  

Take care near the areas of concern and be aware of your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels throughout the day and this message will be updated by 5pm Monday 19th December.

River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River due to rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. River levels are falling at the Maiden Newton gauge. Further rain is forecast for today so we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Parrett (upper) from South Perrott to Thorney
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Chiselborough river gauge as a result of the persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and potentially properties is imminent, although river levels are expected to peak shortly, on the 19/12/22.  We expect flooding to affect the River Parrett downstream of Gawbridge, the A356 at Chiselborough, the Norton Sub Hamdon to Stratton road and Parrett Works near Martock.   
Our incident response staff have cleared weed screens. And we are closely monitoring the situation. If you have further detailed information please let us know.
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated later today 19/12/22; as soon as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected between 7am this morning until Tuesday evening, 20 December 2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around the River East Stour, particularly around Mersham and also along the Aylesford Stream, particularly in Willesborough. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday, 21 December 2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and our partners, and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 

This message will be updated this evening, Monday 19 December 2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising steadily on the Lower Dorset Frome due to the heavy rainfall yesterday and overnight. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham. Further rain is forecast for today so we will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: Rivers Otter and Sid, and Exmouth area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday evening and overnight into Monday morning.

Throughout Sunday 18 December 2022 heavy rainfall has been falling in the East Devon area and is forecast to continue for the next couple of days. This will cause water levels in the River Otter, River Sid and Exmouth area to rise.

Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected. We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the early part of this week and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Monday 19 December 2022 or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Avon, River Erme, River Harbourne

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday evening and overnight into Monday morning.
Throughout Sunday 18 December 2022 heavy rainfall has been falling in the South Devon Rivers area and is forecast to continue for the next couple of days. This will cause water levels in the Rivers Harbourne, Avon and Erme to rise. 
Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected. 
We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the early part of this week and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Monday 19 December 2022 or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Yealm and a Flood Alert remains in force.  

Further rain is forecast this afternoon and evening on Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise late afternoon and into the evening.  

Take care near the areas of concern and be aware of your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels throughout the day and this message will be updated by 5pm Monday 19th December.

The River Adur is high and rising, following 25mm of rain on Sunday. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens along the River Adur. Another 5mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022, and a further 15mm of rain is possible on Monday evening too. Flood impacts should remain minor, but if the River Adur receives all the forecast rain, then flooding could approach property at Slaughter Bridge on the Coolham Road, as well as isolated farm buildings, fields and rural roads between Coolham and Henfield, and gardens of Church Close, Shipley. River levels should begin to fall by Tuesday afternoon (20/12/2022). However, with unsettled weather forecast for the next five days, the river could remain higher than normal all week. Plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including the Coolham Road at Slaughter Bridge. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. From 17:00 on 19/12/2022, the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

Water levels in the Lukely Brook at Newport have now fallen. Some rain (10 mm) is forecast for the remainder of today (19/12/2022). This may cause an increase in water levels, but we do not expect it to have any significant impacts. Showery weather is forecast for the next few days. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. We will issue further advice if additional rainfall causes a significant rise in the water levels.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Stilebridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected from 8am this morning until Tuesday evening, 20 December 2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the river Beult, particularly around Smarden and Bethersden. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday, 21 December 2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated this evening, Monday 19 December 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Axe (Upper) from Winsham to Axminster, including Chard Junction and Weycroft
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is expected on Sunday evening (18/12/22) and into the early hours of Monday morning. Heavy rain falling across the East Devon area over the last 10 hours, has caused the River Axe to rise rapidly and flooding of property is imminent. We expect flooding to affect riverside locations and roads between Winsham and Axminster, including Chard Junction, Coaxden Cottages and Weycroft. Highway flooding is expected at Tytherleigh and Broom, and the A358 crossing at Weycroft. The B3165 at Mosterton and Clapton will start to flood first. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now and install any flood protection products you may have. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Monday (19/12/22) or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Axe (Lower) from Axminster to Axmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is expected on Sunday evening (18/12/22) and into the early hours of Monday morning. Heavy rain falling across the East Devon area over the last 12 hours, has caused the River Axe to rise rapidly and flooding of property is imminent. We expect flooding to affect properties and low lying areas around Whitford Road between Whitford and Musbury, the A3052 at Colyford, the A35 at Yarty Bridge, Seaton Marshes. Farms and other isolated properties between Axminster and Axmouth will start to flood first. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now and install any flood protection products you may have. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Monday (19/12/22) or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Lynher and a Flood Alert remains in force.  

Further rain is forecast this afternoon and evening on Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise late afternoon and into the evening.  

Take care near the areas of concern and be aware of your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels throughout the day and this message will be updated by 5pm Monday 19th December.

items.description: River Avon from Didworthy to Aveton Gifford
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is expected on Sunday 18th December and overnight into Monday 19th December. Rain has been falling in the area and is causing the River Avon to rise. Properties and low lying areas in South Brent, Avonwick, Brushford and Manor House near Diptford Gara Bridge, Loddiswell and Aveton Gifford will start to flood first. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. We are monitoring river levels and this message will be updated on Monday 19th December or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Brit at Newtown, and Southgate Old Mill, Beaminster
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. River levels are falling at the Beaminster river level gauge. Further rain is forecast for today so we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Upper Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. River levels are falling at the Maiden Newton gauge. Further rain is forecast for today so we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels are high on the River Piddle due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
River levels are high at the Briantspuddle gauge.
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall today. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from midnight tonight until Tuesday evening, 20 December 2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around the River Brede, particularly around Winchelsea and also low lying land and roads along the River Tillingham between Broad Oak and Rye. 

Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours and we expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday, 21 December 2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and our partners and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Monday 19 December 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Pen Mill and other river gauges as a result of the persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and farmland is possible today, the 19/12/22.  
We expect flooding to affect the following roads: the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road and the road at the south end of Westover Trading Estate. Properties at Westover Trading Estate at Langport are at risk. Bankfull conditions are forecast at Ilchester, water may reach the bottom of the ringbanks.
We expect river levels to remain high, above the Flood Alert threshold, at least until this afternoon.
Our incident response staff have checked operational assets, the Parrett Relief channel is running, and some pumping stations are becoming inhibited by the high river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated later today, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
While the risk of flooding from St Austell and Par rivers has now reduced, a Flood Alert remains in force. Further rain is forecast this afternoon and evening on Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise late afternoon and into the evening.  

Take care near the areas of concern and be aware of your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels throughout the day and this message will be updated by 5pm Monday 19th December.

Further rain is forecast this afternoon and evening on Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise late afternoon and into the evening. 

Take care near the areas of concern and be aware of your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels throughout the day and this message will be updated by 5pm Monday 19th December.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Polegate Brook Street Stream, Wannock Mill Stream

items.message: River levels through Polegate are returning nearer to normal, following 40mm of rain on Sunday. Another 5mm of rain is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022, and a further 15mm of rain is possible on Monday evening too. However, river levels are not expected to rise as far, and only minimal or minor flood impacts are expected through the rest of the week. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We routinely clear debris from our grilles on Gosford Way to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hayle, Perrancoombe Stream, Bolingey Stream, River Cober, Portreath Stream

items.message:
While the risk of flooding from West Cornwall Rivers has now reduced, a Flood Alert remains in force. Further rain is forecast this afternoon and evening on Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise late afternoon and into the evening. 

Take care near the areas of concern and be aware of your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels throughout the day and this message will be update by 5pm Monday 19th December.

On Sunday, 25mm of rain was recorded in Havant. The River Ems has risen a small amount. Only minimal flood impacts are currently expected. Another 5mm of rain is forecast between 09:00 and 12:00 on Monday 19/12/2022. A further 15mm of rain is possible Monday evening and through the early hours of Tuesday. If as much rain falls as predicted, from 22:00 19/12/2022 minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads and gardens on North Street, River Street, at the Wren Centre, Westbourne, and also near Lumley Mill and Victoria Terrace, Emsworth. The river should begin to fall by 09:00 Tuesday 20/12/2022. However, the River Ems could remain higher than normal into January. As a precaution, we recommend flood protection products are to be installed in Westbourne and Emsworth, if you have them. Flooding could occur in a short space of time, so please be prepared. We are operating our structure at Constant Springs and clearing grilles to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. If the heaviest rain avoids the River Ems, we will remove this message by 11:00 20/12/2022.

Further rain is forecast this afternoon and evening on Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise late afternoon and into the evening.  

Take care near the areas of concern and be aware of your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels throughout the day and this message will be updated by 5pm Monday 19th December.

items.description: River Yealm at Yealmbridge and Yealmpton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Yealm has now reduced, but a Flood Alert remains in force. Further rain is forecast for this afternoon and evening, Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise again but not as high as seen yesterday.

items.description: River Char at Dolphins River Caravan Park
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. River levels are falling at the Charmouth river level gauge. Further rain is forecast for today so we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. River levels are falling at the Charmouth river level gauge. Further rain is forecast for today so we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels have risen at the Chetnole river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and potentially properties is imminent. River levels may peak over the next few hours but rise again after the heavy rainfall and so the risk remains overnight, between 18/12/22 and 19/12/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Chubbs Farm area and at Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole; please ensure you avoid the ford.   
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. If you have further detailed information please let us know.
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated on 19/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Issued in error.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Monday 19th December 2022. River levels are gently rising, and may remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas along the River Mardyke between North Stifford and Purfleet. There may be some further light rainfall overnight. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 20th December.
